attack.translation[0].definitions[0].def: an act of violence that is intended to hurt a person or damage a place
attack.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: an arson attack (=an attempt to destroy a building using fire)
There have been several attacks on foreigners recently.
attack.translation[0].definitions[1].def: the act of using weapons against an enemy in a war
attack.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: Rebel forces launched (=started) an  attack late Sunday night.
Once again we came under attack from enemy fighter planes.
attack.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a strong and direct criticism of someone or something
attack.translation[0].definitions[2].not: go on the attack (=start to criticize someone severely)
attack.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The company has come under fierce attack for its decision to close the factory.
The magazine recently published a vicious personal attack on the novelist.
attack.translation[0].definitions[3].def: a sudden short period of suffering from an illness, especially an illness that you have often
attack.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: He died after suffering a severe asthma attack.
I had a bad attack of flu at Christmas.
attack.translation[0].definitions[4].def: a short period of time when you suddenly feel extremely frightened or worried and cannot think normally or deal with the situation
attack.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: Her heart began to pound frantically, as if she were having a panic attack.
attack.translation[0].definitions[5].def: actions that are intended to get rid of or stop something such as a system, a set of laws etc
attack.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: The new measures were seen by many as an attack on the Scottish way of life.
attack.translation[0].definitions[6].def: an attempt by a player or group of players to score goals or win points
attack.translation[0].definitions[7].def: the players in a team that are responsible for trying to score goals or win points
attack.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: Heath will play alongside Smith in attack.
attack.translation[0].definitions[8].def: when something such as a disease, insect, or chemical damages something
attack.translation[0].definitions[8].exa: Unfortunately, the carved ceilings have suffered woodworm attack over the years.
attack.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 1: an act of violence that is intended to hurt a person or damage a place
attack.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Animal rights activists are believed to have carried out the bomb attack.
The accused men went on trial Monday for America’s worst-ever terrorist attack.
He was sentenced to nine years in prison for the knife attack.
Ten classrooms were completely destroyed in the arson attack.
Police described it as an extremely violent attack.
'This was a horrific attack, ' said Detective Chief Superintendent Ron Astles.
The woman was stabbed to death in a frenzied attack at her home.
Staffordshire police are treating the incident as a racial attack.
There was no indication of a sexual attack.
Their teenage son was knocked to the ground, kicked and punched in an unprovoked attack.
He was stabbed to death in an apparently motiveless attack.
The man who carried out the attack has been described as white and 25 to 32 years old.
The attack took place at around 10 pm Thursday.
The killing follows a series of brutal attacks on tourists.
She was the victim of an attack in her own home.
attack.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 2: the act of using weapons against an enemy in a war
attack.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: They would not risk a nuclear attack on the United States.
General Smith was in favour of an all-out attack on the enemy.
German troops launched a full-scale attack on the city.
Armed attacks against Israeli settlements are on the increase.
We launched a surprise attack on their camp just before dawn.
There were 15 dead and 20 wounded in a missile attack on the capital.
Malta was under heavy air attack.
In April the French army launched an attack.
The King now prepared to mount an attack on Granada.
Camps in the south came under attack from pro-government forces.
He arrived when the base was under attack from mortar and small arms fire.
attack.translation[0].note_box[2].sectio: an act of using weapons against an enemy in a war
The US was threatening to launch an attack on Iran.
The men had been carrying out rocket attacks on British forces.
Bombs have been falling throughout the night, and the city is still under attack  (=being attacked).
invasion
an occasion when an army enters a country and tries to take control of it
The Allies began their invasion of Europe.
The threat of foreign invasion is very real.
raid
a short attack on a place by soldiers or planes, intended to cause damage but not take control
an air raid
NATO warplanes carried out a series of bombing raids on the city.
The village has been the target of frequent raids by rebel groups.
strike
a sudden military attack, especially after a serious disagreement
Senior Israeli officials warned that they were still considering a military strike.
the possibility of a nuclear strike
assault
a military attack intended to take control of a city, area, or building controlled by an enemy
The final military assault on Kwangju began at 3 am on May 27.
Hitler launched an all-out assault  (=using as many soldiers, weapons, planes etc as possible) on Russia.
ambush
a sudden attack by people who have been waiting and hiding, especially an attack on a vehicle or people who are travelling somewhere
Five soldiers were shot in the back and killed in the ambush.
Enemy forces waiting in ambush opened fire on the vehicle.
counterattack
a military attack made in response to an attack by an enemy
Government forces launched a counterattack against the guerillas.
If they successfully occupied the city, they would need to be capable of defending it against enemy counterattack.
onslaught
a large violent attack by an army
In 1544 there was a full-scale onslaught on France, in which the English took Boulogne.
The troops were preparing for another onslaught against the enemy.
attack.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to deliberately use violence to hurt a person or damage a place
attack.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: She was attacked while walking home late at night.
His shop was attacked by a gang of youths.
Snakes will only attack if you disturb them.
He needed 200 stitches after being attacked with a broken bottle.
attack.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to start using guns, bombs etc against an enemy in a war
attack.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Army tanks attacked a village near the capital on Sunday.
attack.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to criticize someone or something very strongly
attack.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Last year Dr Travis publicly attacked the idea that abortion should be available on demand.
Newspapers attacked the government for failing to cut taxes.
attack.translation[1].definitions[3].def: if something such as a disease, insect, or chemical attacks something, it damages it
attack.translation[1].definitions[3].exa: a cruel disease that attacks the brain and nervous system
attack.translation[1].definitions[4].def: to begin to do something in a determined and eager way
attack.translation[1].definitions[4].exa: She immediately set about attacking the problem.
Martin attacked his meal  (=started eating) with vigour.
attack.translation[1].definitions[5].def: to move forward and try to score goals or win points
attack.translation[1].definitions[5].exa: Brazil began to attack more in the second half of the match.
attack.translation[1].note_box[0].sectio: to attack a person
to use violence against someone and try to hurt them
She was attacked by a man with a baseball bat.
Police dogs are trained to attack.
ambush
if a group of people ambush someone, they hide and wait for them and then attack them
The judge was ambushed by gunmen as he drove to work at the courthouse.
mug
to attack someone and take money from them in a public place such as a street
He was mugged on his way home from school.
stab
to attack someone with a knife
The victim had been stabbed in the neck.
assault
to attack and hurt someone – used especially when talking about this as a criminal offence
He assaulted a flight attendant who refused to serve him more drinks.
be set upon by somebody/something
to be attacked by a group of people
He died outside his home after being set upon by a gang of youths.
turn on
to suddenly change your behaviour and attack the person you are with, when they do not expect this
The dog suddenly turned on him, sinking its teeth into his arm.
to attack a place
to use weapons to try to damage or take control of a place
The village was attacked by enemy warplanes.
We will attack at dawn.
invade
to enter a country and try to get control of it using force
The Romans invaded Britain 2,000 years ago.
storm
to suddenly attack a city or building that is well defended by getting inside it and taking control
Elite troops stormed the building and rescued the hostages.
besiege
to surround a city or building with soldiers in order to stop the people inside from getting out or from receiving supplies
In April 655, Osman’s palace was besieged by rebels.
